definition: **noun / lab setup term.** A **test configuration where two cartridges are mounted at 90-degree (X-Y) axes** to evaluate channel separation and crosstalk — used by cartridge designers and archivists. The setup positions one cartridge to read the lateral (left-right) groove modulation while the second reads vertical (up-down) movement, allowing precise measurement of how well a stereo cartridge isolates left and right channels. Developed in the early 1960s alongside stereo record standardization, the X-Y test became essential for manufacturers like Shure and Ortofon to verify that their designs met the 20-30 dB channel separation targets required for convincing stereo imaging. Engineers use specialized test records with out-of-phase signals or single-channel tones to quantify crosstalk — the unwanted bleed of one channel into another. High crosstalk (poor separation) causes a collapsed, mono-like soundstage, while excellent separation above 25 dB preserves spatial information and instrument placement. Archivists restoring vintage recordings employ X-Y testing to select cartridges that minimize inter-channel contamination. Modern implementations often use electronic phase analysis rather than dual cartridges, but the X-Y principle remains the gold standard for evaluating stereo pickup performance in both quality control and restoration work.
etymology: Named for the X-Y coordinate system in mathematics, referring to the perpendicular axes at which the two test cartridges are mounted, corresponding to lateral and vertical groove modulation in stereo records.
